Address.StreetName: SB CAPITAL BELTWAY @ RITCHIE MARLBORO RD

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
L-35 is equipped with a mobile recording device, this incident was recorded. This incident was also recorded with ID #7353 body-worn camera.

Defendant: Marlon Antonio Marquez-Parada

Date of Birth: 10/19/1998

Date of Arrest: 03/05/2023

Time of Arrest: 0009  hours

DC License #: 4634083

DUI #: 23-070

 

TRAINING/CERTIFICATES


 

  • Trained in administering Standardized Field Sobriety Tests through the Maryland State Police and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration on December 5th-8th, 2022.

  • Trained in administering Preliminary Breath Tests through the Maryland State Police Forensics Science Division on December 9, 2022.

 

Vehicle in Motion (Phase 1): 

 

On 03/04/2023 at approximately 0045 hours, I, Trooper Stacey #7390, was operating marked MSP vehicle L-35 and was traveling southbound on I-495 n/o Richie Marlboro Road, in Prince George’s County, MD. At this time I observed a black Ford Escape bearing DC registration JC5144, traveling in lane #4 and the operator was using a handheld device while the vehicle was in motion. I got behind the vehicle and activated my emergency equipment. It should be noted that it took the driver a prolonged time to pull over.

 

Personal Contact (Phase 2): 

 

Upon my driver’s side approach I made contact with the driver, whom I later identified as Marlon Antonio Marquez-Parada (H/M, DOB 10/19/1998). I immediately detected a moderate odor of an alcoholic beverage emanating from the vehicle. I observed a black bag in the passenger seat with a 6-pack of glass bottles inside. At this time I went to the passenger side of the vehicle to further investigate. Once I was on the passenger side, I observed one opened glass bottle of an alcoholic beverage on the passenger side floorboard. It was sitting upright and appeared to have been spilled recently. When I asked Marquez-Parada how many alcoholic beverages he that night he said he had nothing to drink. I then asked Marquez-Parada to exit the vehicle to perform Standardized Field Sobriety Tests. Once Marquez-Parada exited the vehicle, I detected a moderate odor of an alcoholic beverage emanating from his breath and person. At this time, I also noticed his eyes to be glassy and bloodshot.

 

Pre-Arrest Screening (Phase 3):

The evaluation was performed on the right shoulder of the highway. The weather was clear and cold, approximately 40 degrees. Lighting conditions were dark. The ground was level and free of any debris. My patrol vehicle’s overhead emergency lights in the front were deactivated prior to field sobriety tests as well as the vehicles spot light. Marquez-Parada appeared to be in good physical condition and did not display any visible signs of injuries as a result of the collision.
 

I asked Marquez Parada the following questions:

 

Medication: none

Medical Conditions: Asthma

 

Marquez Parada was asked to remove his glasses for the Standardized Field Sobriety Tests.

HORIZONTAL GAZE NYSTAGMUS  (6/6 clues observed)

 

The first test given was the Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus test. The tip of my pen was used as the test stimulus and held approximately 12 inches from his eyes. Marquez-Parada was instructed to look straight ahead, keeping his head still while following and focusing on the tip of the stimulus with his eyes. Marquez-Parada pupils were of equal size and showed equal tracking.
 

Marquez-Parada displayed the following clues:

 

  1. Lack of Smooth Pursuit - Present in both eyes

  2. Distinct and Sustained Nystagmus at Maximum Deviation - Present in both eyes

  3. Onset of Nystagmus Prior to 45 Degrees - Present in both eyes

 

 

WALK AND TURN TEST (3/8 clues observed)

 

Prior to Marquez-Parada taking the test, I properly explained and demonstrated how the test should be conducted. Marquez-Parada was instructed to place his right foot directly in front of his left foot and touch heel to toe on an imaginary line. Marquez-Parada was instructed and demonstrated to place his hands flat at his sides and to remain in that position until told to begin. Marquez-Parada was advised to take nine (9) steps in a straight line touching heel to toe on every step. Marquez-Parada was instructed to keep his hands flat at his sides, keep his eyes focused on his feet, and to count every step aloud. On the ninth step, Marquez-Parada was explained and demonstrated to keep his lead foot on the line, and to take a series of small steps around with his rear foot to the left to turn completely around. Marquez-Parada was again explained and demonstrated the second series of nine (9) steps were to be performed identical to the first series. Marquez-Parada was instructed that once he began the test that he was not to stop walking until the test was completed, keep his hands down by his side, look down at his feet, and count each step out loud.

 

Instructional Stage:

 

  • Cannot keep balance during instruction

 

Walking Stage (1st set of nine steps):

 

  1. Does not touch heel to toe 

  2. Improper turn

 

Walking Stage (2nd set of nine steps):

 

  1. Does not touch heel to toe

  2. Improper turn

 

 

 

ONE LEG STAND (1/4 clues observed)

 

Prior to Marquez-Parada performing the test, I properly explained and demonstrated how the test should be conducted. He was instructed to stand with his feet together and hands down by his side while the instructions were given. During the test he was instructed not to begin the test until he was instructed to start once the test had been demonstrated. When instructed to start, he was to raise the foot of his choice off the ground approximately 6 inches. While his leg was raised he was to keep his leg straight, watch his raised foot, and to count out loud by thousands (one-thousand-one, one thousand-two) and to continue the test until told to stop.

 

Marquez-Parada displayed the following clues:

 

Foot Down:

0 to 10 sec’s

21 to 30 sec’s

 

Marquez-Parada was offered a Preliminary Breath Test to which he accepted with a result of .16 BrAC.

 

ARREST

 

Based on the following, I had reason to believe Cheshier was operating a motor vehicle under the influence of alcohol:

 

  • Odor of an alcoholic beverage emitting from vehicle and his breath

  • Took a extended amount of time to pull over

  • Glass bottle on passenger side floorboard

  • Eyes glassy and bloodshot

  • Odor of an alcoholic beverage

  • Clues observed during field sobriety

 

 

Marquez-Parada was arrested at 0009 hours. Marquez-Parada was transported to the Maryland State Police Forestville Barrack. At approximately 0031 hours, Marquez-Parada listened to the Spanish audio recording of the DR15 which was played aloud in the barrack. Marquez-Parada refused to take the intoximeter test. Marquez-Parada was given the appropriate citations and was released to his significant other at 0102 hours.

 

All of the above events occurred in Prince George’s County, Maryland.
